About the creator
The creator of Stump Armour is a medically retired Marine Gunnery Sergeant who participated in the 100 Entrepreneurs Project.  100 Entrepreneurs help was paramount in getting this project going.  On top of extensive military experience he has also graduated Entrepreneurial Bootcamp for Veterans (EBV) at Texas A&M’s Mays Business School.  Stump Armour is one of 2 medical patents he has pending.  He has made a career out of solving problems and continues to do so post active duty service.  
WWW.STUMPARMOUR.COM
Email questions to info@stumparmour.com

story:
Healthier for everyone

We believe that product designers have a responsibility to make sustainable products. Too many products today are made purely for profit and destined for landfill.

Most drug store toothbrushes are made using petroleum-based plastic, which is cheap, abundant, easy to work with, but doesn't decompose. Putting 3 billion a year (and growing) into landfill is simply not sustainable.

Our goal was to design a toothbrush that is worth owning and reduces the amount of plastic required. Our brush heads use approximately 85% less plastic than regular drug store brand toothbrushes and is made using recyclable ABS. 

The bristles are made of DuPont Nylon 6 (the most biodegradable nylon on the market).

We are committed to finding the best possible materials for your mouth and the planet.

  • Handle – Anodized aluminum (a process that converts the metal surface into a durable, corrosion-resistant, brightly coloured finish that won't chip or wear off over time)
  • Brush – ABS plastic (100% recyclable)
  • Bristles – DuPont Nylon 6 
  • grin's handle weighs approximately 35 grams
  • each grin brush head weighs approximately 3.5 grams

 

 


grin helps solve 3 major problems with disposable, plastic toothbrushes.

1. They're not very hygienic

Cheap, plastic toothbrushes are designed with one goal in mind: to look expensive. They're covered in grooves that quickly get gunked up with old toothpaste, saliva and bacteria (we keep them in our bathrooms, after all). Plus the bristles turn wiry and get bits of old food stuck in the bottom. 

Any idea how old your toothbrush is? Dentists recommend you replace it every 3 months. That's around 180 uses. Would you ever use a plastic fork twice?

2. Who wants to shop for a toothbrush?

Shopping for a toothbrush isn't fun. Standing in front of a wall of 30 or 40 different toothbrushes that look alike is overwhelming. Plus, forgetting to buy a new one leaves you using your old, bacteria-covered toothbrush.

3. They’re disposable

Each year we dispose of over 3 billion plastic toothbrushes, most of which end up in our landfills or oceans. This is senseless, unnecessary and a great opportunity to make something better. So we reinvented the toothbrush.

 

We need your help!

Your contributions will help us:

  • Create the molds that are used to manufacture the handle and brush heads
  • Manufacture the very first set of toothbrushes
  • Design the product packaging (in the works!)
  • Complete our marketing website
  • Fund our initial marketing campaign as we spread the word

Our goal is to create a toothbrush that is of the highest quality. Let's put a dent in ~ 165,346,696 pounds of plastic toothbrushes that clog up our planet every year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We're thrilled with grin and your support, but we're just getting started.

Here are some of the things we're looking for your support with:

  • Help us name the colours! We would love your ideas for our blue, green and magenta colour names.
  • Let us know what you would like as the next grin colour. Orange? Purple?
  • If you are aware of any environmentally friendly materials that could work for our bristles, please let us know.

 

FAQ's

Q. I can just buy a disposable, plastic toothbrush at the grocery store for $4. Why should I pay more for grin?

A. Yes, grin is more expensive. But it is a superior quality toothbrush. Plus, it comes to you by mail so you'll never have to stand in front of a wall of toothbrushes that all look identical, yet vary a bit in price. That is one of my biggest frustrations as a consumer – too much choice. Do we really need 45 different options for what is basically a throwaway toothbrush? 

The second point is that if we as consumers want to be more responsible in what we consume, then unfortunately, we will usually have to pay more. Plastic is incredibly easy to work with and costs little to produce, but it's very, very bad for the planet. I believe that in the future we will be forced (through scarcity of oil, which is what plastic is made of) – to consume fewer yet smarter products. grin is just such a product.

Q. If grin's brush head is made of plastic, how is it better than a plastic toothbrush?

A. To make a toothbrush that is hygienic and Dentist approved, we need to use plastic. grin's brush head will be made out of ABS plastic, which is 100% recyclable. Unfortunately, the nylon bristles are not. So to recycle to brush head people would need to remove the bristles. We understand that this is not a reality for most people, so we worked hard to design a brush head which uses minimal plastic.

In fact, grin's brush head uses 85% less plastic than an ordinary drug store toothbrush. So even if you use a new grin brush head every month for a year, you would still be using less plastic (~42 grams) than 2 regular toothbrushes (~50 grams for 2).

As grin continues to develop, my hope is that we can find plastic that can decompose quickly and is safe for use.

Q. How much will it cost to order brush head replacements?

A. We're hoping to offer replacements for about $5 each including shipping. To keep costs down we will likely mail people replacement brush heads in packs of 3, then send a friendly email reminder on a monthly or bi-monthly basis. 

But for users who are gentle on their toothbrushes, we will offer replacement toothbrush heads on an as-needed basis. Just log in and order a 3 pack whenever you need to.

If you have a question, please send an email to: simon@grinbrush.com

 

Thank you

We spent a year designing grin and are thrilled with the result. grin is a simple, beautiful toothbrush that we believe you'll be happy to own. 

Thank you for helping us reach our goal.

story:
What is kaiRos?

kaiRos is a community of specialists from the health sector who are unifying to improve therapeutic methods for those with executive functioning impairments. Included in this community are psychiatrists, psychologists, neurologists, life coaches, general practitioners, massage therapists, learning strategists, and the like.


What is the kaiRos Approach?

The kaiRos Approach is an affordable, exceptional, hands-on, therapeutic method which enables those with executive functioning impairments to establish essential coping mechanisms. It teaches the client how to sift through the general noise and confusion of daily life, and helps them figure out how to eliminate the noise. The kaiRos approach is highly customizable and is tailored to the individual client, accounting for such things as personality and behavioural differences, learning and communication styles, and individual goals.

How did the kaiRos Approach come to be?

kaiRos founder, Leah Kazmerik, is the pioneer of the kaiRos Approach. Years of struggling through the healthcare system with little to no success lead to paralyzing amounts of frustration. She frequently turned to her journal as a means of working through roadblocks and consistently found herself writing of a place she wished existed. One particularly trying experience had Leah venting her frustration to her mentor, Robert Harris, and lamenting the fact that there was no place which offered the kind of care she required. It simply did not, and could not, exist. Robert’s response: “Why can’t there be?” This inspired her to entertain the possibility that it could. The two then began the process of brainstorming what has come to be known as the kaiRos Approach.

“I found a way to not get lost in the system.” – Leah Kazmerik

What is different about the kaiRos Approach?

Other forms of therapeutic care often have difficulty manifesting tangible results from theoretical or philosophical discussions undergone in removed locations. kaiRos uses emerging remedial methods alongside in-context coaching to help establish practical daily habits through the use of in-depth intake assessments, expedited appointments with medical specialists, and one-on-one coaching in-context.

Why is the kaiRos Approach necessary?

At kaiRos we believe that absolutely everyone is born to do something with his or her life. When this purpose is not fulfilled, or is in some way perceived as impossible to achieve, the result is a deep brokenness and desolation that no one should have to endure.  

Low self-esteem, challenges to social function, and previous challenges to success decrease likelihood of receiving successful therapeutic care, particularly for those with executive functioning impairment. The kaiRos Approach provides hands-on guidance through the chaos and confusion of the diagnosis and treatment process to ensure successful results.

How can I partner with kaiRos?

At present our greatest need is funding. Since the kaiRos Approach is not compatible with the current Alberta Health Services system most of our process has to be paid out of pocket. Ideally we would raise enough money to operate fully as well as offer scholarships and stipends for clients with financial struggles.

We are currently looking for qualified coaches in order to assist a greater number of people. Prior experience in psychology, counselling, or coaching is required, as well as a willingness to walk with our clients through any challenges they may be facing.

We are always interested in networking with passionate, informed healthcare professionals with whom we can collaborate to better assist our clients. We are looking for individuals with a history of success working with clients in various psychological and psychiatric fields, such as: ADHD, mood disorders, personality disorders, neurodevelopmental disorders, and learning disabilities. Expert knowledge in the field of improving executive function is necessary.

When will the kaiRos Approach be available?

We will begin the screening process for the proof of concept with our clients on June 1, 2016. We are expecting to open our doors fully shortly thereafter.

How are you spending our money?

Based on preliminary forecasts, forty to fifty percent of funds raised will be used to cover administrative costs. The remaining amount will be devoted to covering all coaching costs and assisting clients with financial needs to cover any necessary specialist fees. Because the method has not yet been fully proven, we have endeavoured to assist these clients to ensure their investment does not outweigh their means.

Meet our Team

Leah Kazmerik – CEO

Leah Kazmerik is a jack of all trades with a passion for people. After having significant challenges being diagnosed and treated for a brain injury, she uses her innate people and networking skills to find a better way to diagnose and treat her own, and related, challenges. She acts as Chief Strategy Officer and Intake Officer for The kaiRos Approach, using her poor experience in the healthcare system to develop a new method of integrity, compassion, and community. In the little spare time she has, Leah successfully maintains a full time job in sales at Best Buy, researches and integrates new findings in the neuropsychiatry and neuropsychology fields, watches geeky movies, and entertains a deep passion for technology and innovation.


Carly Vandersteen – COO

Carly Vandersteen is a theology student who focuses on leadership development. She values people highly and endeavours to treat everyone as kindly and respectfully as their inherent worth deserves. Her love of people and organization are what drive her to perform within kaiRos.


Coreen Pearce – CFO, Financial Manager

Coreen Pearce began her work in banking, and after several years she achieved the Dealer Finance position. When she had 2 children, both boys, she ventured out to begin her own cleaning company in order to have more time to invest in her children. She now works as an independent agent for World Financial Group and has been doing so for the past eight years.


Richard Kazmerik – CM&CO

Richard Kazmerik has been working in management for fifteen years across many retail avenues. He currently maintains a full-time position at Indigo as the Task Manager, while also working for kaiRos as the Chief Marketing and Communications Officer. Both of these roles allow Richard to fulfill his passion of providing people the tools they need to succeed.


Chelsea Friesen –  Social Media Manager, Artistic Director

Chelsea Friesen is a Theatre Student and all-around artist who has created everything from 4’x3’ acrylic paintings to album artwork, from clay sculptures to graphic designs. She grew up in a reserved rural Alberta home where she learned the value of hard work, integrity, and loyalty, not to mention the pivotal role of community in one’s overall wellbeing.  Chelsea offers her talents to kaiRos in the forms of graphic designs, advertizing, and social media management.


Tammy Morency – Coach

Tammy Morency has been involved with the kaiRos approach from the beginning stages, when it was merely a dream. She has been coaching for over a year and has helped her clients find great success. Despite the demanding nature of the job, she maintains a fulfilling life rhythm, finding time for such things as biking, walking, and swimming when the weather permits, or a good book or movie when nature is unwilling to cooperate.


Joanna Curyk – Coach

Joanna was born in Poland and lived there until the age of 4 when she moved to Canada.  Raised in Calgary, she has traveled Eastern Europe and completed a student exchange in Austria.  She has always had a thirst for knowledge, a passion for helping people and an interest in Psychology.  With a Minor in Psychology at the University of Calgary, as part of her multidisciplinary BA Degree, she is eager to work with the team at kaiRos as a Coach.  Joanna will be working closely with clients to provide one-on-one support while they work towards achieving their goals


Adam Turner – Coach

Adam Turner was born and raised in Calgary where he has worked in a variety of industries, seeking to find his true passion. This has led him to pursue an undergraduate degree in psychology at the University of Calgary where he hopes to continue his education to obtain a Masters degree. At kaiRos he provides one-on-one coaching in-context.

story:
Do you love dogs?

We do. If there was a way you could pet a dog right now, would you do it? We would. Imagine that: pull out your phone, find a dog (and their owner) five minutes away who’s ready to let you rub their belly, toss them a frisbee, or just pet them and tell them they are h*ckin' good puppers. As a dog owner, imagine getting a ping - someone starved for a dog's attention is 5 minutes away, and willing to pay to play with your dog (who could use a little more exercise, let’s be honest.) In short, this is a world of "dogs on demand," where owners and seekers win, and pups get all the affection.

If this all sounds like a fantasy, that's because it is...right now. This service does not yet exist, but we have a plan to build it...All we need is a little help.

We are Pat, Bob, and Nate; we have been friends since we were kids and have always dreamed of doing something big together. We’ve been doing things together our whole lives. We grew up together. We have traveled the world together. We have suffered and triumphed together. Now we want to try to build something meaningful together.

Given our shared history, it only seemed natural that our project would be something that helps make connections. That is how we came up with idea for Pupprrr. We have a vision for an app/ service that will allow people to connect with dogs (and their humans) in their local area.

What We Need & What You Get - Straight.Up.SWAG. 

To make this dream project a reality, we need to raise around $30k. That funding will help us get operational (target date is May 2018).

But wait, what's in it for you? (besides the best app in the world?) Well, we hate asking people for anything, so we want to offer some unique perks for those who help us out.

  • Founders' Circle ($1000 or more) - First off, we have a limited number of vouchers for custom infusions for the high rollers out there. We infused these craft spirits ourselves with recipes Nate has been perfecting over the past year, then we put them in a bottle covered in custom, limited edition artwork designed by Pat.
  • Yo, I got you ($500) - For those still pretty high rollers, we also have custom art created by Pat that we had printed on aircraft aluminum. We wanted to show you that we are serious about our project so we got serious about creating some art for you. Each one includes a person message from the founders.
  • Lemme Help! ($100) - We couldn't have an app centered around dogs without some sweet, custom dog tagz...
  • Here's My Milk Money ($50) - Every penny we get means the world to us, so we put together these bespoke, personalized thank yous

The A-Team

To get this app off the ground, between the three of us, we have a unique combination of skills and experiences that will help us succeed.

  • Bob is Chief Data Scientist at a leading mental health tech company. He is a Columbia-educated statistician, with years of experience in big data, product management, and user experience. He also knows how to build companies from the ground up, he was the first employee at his current company, which has grown to over 70 staff. 
  • Pat comes to the table with honed business acumen, a trained artistic eye, and a wealth of experience in product development. He is a classically trained artist, a successful web developer with experience running his own design company, and a loving dog owner.
  • Nate adds extensive leadership and project management experience honed in the military, along with legal and business know-how. He is a Harvard-educated lawyer, a management consultant at a top firm, a Naval War College-trained strategist, and the former Captain of a Coast Guard Patrol Boat stationed in Guam. That ship, the Coast Guard Cutter WASHINGTON (WPB-1331) helped save 23 lives in 2013 and earned the distinction of being named the best Coast Guard unit in the Pacific Area.  

Additionally, we have a great plan and have already made significant progress.We have already made extensive progress on our initial design and are engaged in first-round testing on several key elements. We have already maintained an aggressive schedule, and we hope to be moving into coding in January...with a target launch date in May! 

Finally, we have each other! We have been through a lot together and, through it all, we have helped each other thrive. We have faith in each other...and we ask that you use that as a foundation to extend some faith to us as a team. 

Thank you, and we look forward to sharing our product with you and all of the puppers soon :)

We are Pat, Bob, and Nate; we have been friends since we were kids and have always dreamed of doing something big together. We’ve been doing things together our whole lives. We grew up together. We have traveled the world together. We have suffered and triumphed together. Now we want to try to build something meaningful together.
Given our shared history, it only seemed natural that our project would be something that helps make connections. That is how we came up with idea for Pupprrr. We have a vision for an app/ service that will allow people to connect with dogs (and their humans) in their local area.

What We Need & What You Get - Straight.Up.SWAG. 
To make this dream project a reality, we need to raise around $30k. That funding will help us get operational (target date is May 2018).
But wait, what's in it for you? (besides the best app in the world?) Well, we hate asking people for anything, so we want to offer some unique perks for those who help us out.


Founders' Circle ($1000 or more) - First off, we have a limited number of vouchers for custom infusions for the high rollers out there. We infused these craft spirits ourselves with recipes Nate has been perfecting over the past year, then we put them in a bottle covered in custom, limited edition artwork designed by Pat.

Yo, I got you ($500) - For those still pretty high rollers, we also have custom art created by Pat that we had printed on aircraft aluminum. We wanted to show you that we are serious about our project so we got serious about creating some art for you. Each one includes a person message from the founders.

Lemme Help! ($100) - We couldn't have an app centered around dogs without some sweet, custom dog tagz...

Here's My Milk Money ($50) - Every penny we get means the world to us, so we put together these bespoke, personalized thank yous


The A-Team
To get this app off the ground, between the three of us, we have a unique combination of skills and experiences that will help us succeed.

Bob is Chief Data Scientist at a leading mental health tech company. He is a Columbia-educated statistician, with years of experience in big data, product management, and user experience. He also knows how to build companies from the ground up, he was the first employee at his current company, which has grown to over 70 staff. 
Pat comes to the table with honed business acumen, a trained artistic eye, and a wealth of experience in product development. He is a classically trained artist, a successful web developer with experience running his own design company, and a loving dog owner.
Nate adds extensive leadership and project management experience honed in the military, along with legal and business know-how. He is a Harvard-educated lawyer, a management consultant at a top firm, a Naval War College-trained strategist, and the former Captain of a Coast Guard Patrol Boat stationed in Guam. That ship, the Coast Guard Cutter WASHINGTON (WPB-1331) helped save 23 lives in 2013 and earned the distinction of being named the best Coast Guard unit in the Pacific Area.  

Additionally, we have a great plan and have already made significant progress.We have already made extensive progress on our initial design and are engaged in first-round testing on several key elements. We have already maintained an aggressive schedule, and we hope to be moving into coding in January...with a target launch date in May! 
Finally, we have each other! We have been through a lot together and, through it all, we have helped each other thrive. We have faith in each other...and we ask that you use that as a foundation to extend some faith to us as a team. 
Thank you, and we look forward to sharing our product with you and all of the puppers soon :)

story:
False divisions have been created and exploited for years in the beauty industry. Hair products that dominate beauty shelves are not formulated for all hair types and textures and often don’t cater to women, men and children.

DāO designs and creates premium products using plant based and laboratory made ingredients for the entire family. We do this through an improved supply chain process that reduces overall production costs to provide the highest quality products to our customers at the lowest price.

By supporting us, you will help bring our full product line to market and launch a mass #DefyAllOdds advocacy campaign that will help to debunk false beliefs about hair and identity in our global society.

In the beginning, DāO started with just Naturel Daily Moisturizing Spray. People love how it works, how it smells and how it enhances their natural look. After many requests and much anticipation, it is with great pride that DāO seeks to manufacture and produce a full hair product line that includes 6 other products: Moisturizing Shampoo, Deep Conditioner, Leave-In Conditioner, Hair Growth Oil, Non-Flake Hair Gel and Scalp Conditioner.

This is our first time creating something at this scale, yet it’s a nod to the social side of the Detroit community that we’re in where #DefyAllOdds is a way of life.

All of these products are designed and created to be used together in order to experience the full DāO hair transformation and restoration.

DāO starts by sourcing the highest quality plant-based and laboratory made ingredients to inspire and create all product formulations. Each product packs unique essential oils that contribute to comprehensive mind, body and hair healing and restoration.

DāO partners with a family-owned manufacturer who has been in the haircare business over 100 years. By enforcing strict service level agreements, DāO ensures there is little waste in the production process while the premium quality of the product is maintained.

Get Ready to End the Confusion, Frustration and Pain of Caring For Your Natural Hair! It is DāO’s goal to help people understand how to love and nurture their amazing authenticity and #DefyAllOdds.

It starts first with the health of your mind and body which directly reflects in your hair. In today’s fast-paced world, we often neglect caring for ourselves and taking time to be still and breathe. Then it takes great products to nurture your delicate hair as it transitions from damaged to healthy or from dry to well-nourished.

 

Using Naturel Daily Moisturizing Spray will guarantee an immediate shift in your overall hair experience as you find the hair becoming more manageable and restored over time.

When seeking to nurture your long-term hair health, be sure to follow the steps below featuring our divine product line up for beautiful hair at every occasion.

 

Own Your Identity and Dare to Be Different

DāO donates 5% of profits to fund the #DefyAllOdds campaign encouraging young and old from all backgrounds to own their identities and embrace the differences that make them unique. The programs will include nationwide workshops, social media engagement, and community meetups. Outcomes are projected to impact community awareness, dialogue, and social capital as it relates to redefining healthy beauty and lifestyle standards.

Our goal is to cultivate diverse communities that are self-loving and committed to supporting each other and working together to accept others just as they are.

 
Where does your money go?
 
DāO intends to allocate contributions from this campaign to do the following:
  • Purchase high-quality ingredients, sustainable packaging, and other product materials
  • Fund the manufacturing, production, fulfillment and shipment of the full DāO product line 
  • Cover costs associated with marketing, administrative supplies and service fees.

 

 

 

 

Erin Patten is the Cofounder of DāO Detroit, a unisex natural hair care company, and CMO at Potencity, a recruiting platform for high potential diverse professionals. Erin is a purpose-driven creative with a passion for developing communities, designing businesses, and helping people. Erin worked for 5+ years in the NYC fashion industry at luxury department stores Bergdorf Goodman and Lord & Taylor as a personal shopper and online marketer. In 2015, Erin graduated from the joint degree MBA/MPP program at Harvard’s Business School and Kennedy School spending her summers interning at a start-up accelerator in Rio de Janeiro and at Shinola in Detroit. After graduating, Erin served as the Special Assistant to the CEO at the Kresge Foundation and then joined Ponyride Detroit, a non-profit supporting creative and social entrepreneurs, as Director of Retail and Marketing. Erin earned her BBA in Marketing and BA in Plan II Honors from the University of Texas at Austin. 

Willis Marshall has a BA in Public Relations and Advertising from Youngstown State University. As a faith-driven entrepreneur, Willis holds a firm belief that difficult takes a day and impossible takes a week. Currently, he is the Cofounder of DāO Detroit, a unisex natural hair care company, and Founder of Mojo Fitness, a physical health and wellness company with a specialization in aquatic therapy. Willis started Mojo Fitness in Denver in 2009 and has since expanded the company to Phoenix and Detroit. Willis’ unique approach to aquatic therapy training, such as substance abuse coaching, has revolutionized thoughts around addiction treatment. Prior to Mojo Fitness, Willis had a successful 12-year professional football career in the Canadian Football and Arena Football Leagues, winning three National Championships and two MVP Titles between both leagues.

Producing a new line of hair products always has an element of risk: batches can face setbacks due to raw material shortages and machines can malfunction mid-production. DāO has come to realize that setbacks can happen, but having produced a full batch of products with the Naturel Moisturizing Spray from start to finish, we’re confident that we’ve ironed out the lion's share of these issues. Anything that we encounter along the way, well that’s always part of the #DefyAllOdds journey, but we have a great team and we have no doubt that we’ll be able to deal with it. It’s a step up in our production methods but that’s part of the challenge and why it's worthwhile.

If the campaign really takes off, some of you may have to wait a little longer for your products since we have to order more raw materials and packaging goods and we have a limited production capacity. We’ve tried to be conservative with our timeline and we’ll keep you fully updated along the way and promise that your hair transformation will be well worth the wait.

story:
Why I started Tribe

I was not prepared for life as a mom. Then again, who really is? I felt it all – the unexplainable joy mixed with the overwhelming “what did we do?!” sentiment. I know I’m not alone. Most moms go through some form of baby blues: anxiety, loneliness, depression, sleep deprivation, stress, fear, and loss of identity. How on earth can something be so amazing and special, yet so chaotic and confusing? This emotional roller coaster leaves us feeling like we’re on an island, but the truth is, nearly every mom can relate.

There is no shame in this honesty, but most of us don’t talk about it. It’s our tendency to share the happy moments – the picture-perfect moments – but we’re less inclined to simply say, “today is really, really hard.” Personally, I feel drained by the exhaustion. I feel like I need more support and more “me time.” I desire a time when I felt like I was in control of my life. Oh, and I miss my relationship with my husband.

Life will never be the same, though. From the moment we became pregnant, everything changed: mind, body, and spirit. Our identity shifted, and even if this new, 2.0 version of ourselves is better, we have to acknowledge and embrace that life has changed. We have changed.

Motherhood is more than a full-time gig, and generally, we respond to it by putting ourselves last. We give so much of ourselves away immediately. This role requires brain power, muscle, every inch of our heart, and every minute of our day. So, here is my challenge for you, mamas: take care of your mind, body, and spirit.

Our Next Steps

Tribe is moving into an amazing new home! We are sharing a space with an existing 16,000 square foot gym with studio space,  gym equipment, an indoor pool + hot tub, sauna/steam, body work rooms, locker room, and childcare. 

Two elements that are vital to Tribe's success are having a dedicated Tribe Ladies Lounge within the 16,000 gym for our women to congregate before and after classes, and having a top notch childcare studio. And due to us sharing space, being able to add a bit of the Tribe brand and vibe to the large space so that our women feel comfortable and welcome is also a necessity. We need to put resources into these areas to make sure they happen.

Additionally, we want to make joining Tribe even more special with a welcome gift full of educational tools, resources, helpful tips, and Tribe swag.

At this time, we want to add afternoon workshops and gatherings. We plan on having a time dedicated to "sacred space," where women can just be together and talk about what is happening in their lives. We also plan on working with professionals in this field to offer themed workshops and seminars. 

Lastly, we need support staff! Just as how we preach that it takes a village to raise a child, we need extra hands to support Tribe.

Our goal is to raise $20,000

With your donation, we will be able to build out our childcare studio with the highest quality equipment and toys; purchase furniture for our Tribe Ladies Lounge; hire additional support staff; design, print, and buy items for our welcome bags; and to test workshops and seminars.

Funds will be spent in order listed above.

The Impact

At Tribe, magic is happening. In the studio, we hear from women daily about the difference we have made in their lives, how they have made friends, how they don't feel so lonely, how they feel healthier and happier than they have in years, how their postpartum symptoms have disappeared. And when you have healthy and happy mothers, you have healthy and happy children. We also hear from women around the country that keep an eye on what Tribe is up to through our blog and social media platforms. Even from across the country, we are making a difference in their lives. Most recently we received an email from a woman in Brooklyn: "I just read your "about" section on your website and was left in tears. Tears of relief that I can now trust that I'll find community in a new city where I only know one other family. Becoming a mother has indeed been the most incredible and isolating experience of my life and we are about to undergo a huge upheaval by moving to a city that we believe will offer a better life for our little one. So thank you for creating Tribe. I cannot wait to be a part of it!"

Women need Tribe. And we need you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about Tribe! The more members, the more success we have! It really is a community effort and we all have to participate so that women and mothers have these resources and options.

story:
Thank you to everyone who contributed to our project in Round 1. Your contributions will help us fly our founder Sohrab Amiri on the ground and pay for expenses related to his stay for 2 months to work with developers and health facilities. In total, we have raised $1,030 and for that, we are incredibly thankful to those who have shown support and trust into our Cumasu team to fulfill this project. 

However, we still are in need of funding to ensure that Cumasu can run its Pilot Project in order to see how best we can work with health facilities and patients to serve them with the necessities to ensure an improved adherence of appointments and prescription intake for sensitive diseases such as HIV/AIDS. We will include the link to our first round of the sincere support we have received to our pilot project efforts thus far. 

The description of the previous campaign will help demonstrate what will happen with the funding we have raised thus far. 

Introduction

Imagine your name is Maureen from Nairobi, Kenya, working as a hairdresser. You are the only breadwinner for your parents and siblings sometimes working 15 hours a day. You start catching a cold that you cannot seem to shake off, your vision starts to blur, and you are losing a significant amount of weight over time. Despite knowing how important your vision is for your work, you ignore the symptoms. The stigma around it limits your access to diagnosis and treatment. 

Finally, after your sister was able to convince you, you went to a local hospital and got tested for HIV. You are HIV positive. How could this have happened to you?

After a while, the untreated HIV made you blind and you could no longer work because of how long you had to wait to seek diagnosis and treatment due to fear of the stigma around it. Now you are 34 with no partner or children, and you have been contemplating suicide. 

Maureen's story is the embodiment of many more people in which HIV/AIDS has left people in unstable positions within society, ultimately killing them prematurely. According to Avert, there are 4,500 new HIV infections every day among adults 15 years and older. 37% of those infections are among young people (aged 15-24 years), and this is an even worse statistic when we find out that women in the same age group have a higher HIV prevalence than men in the same age group.

My story begins with my parents fleeing to Germany as political refugees. Racism left me ostracized at a young age. From those experiences, questions related to social stigma have been a part of me ever since I can remember. And they have, in part, led me to start my venture, Cumasu, which seeks to address the lack of access to healthcare faced by marginalized communities in developing nations. Specific challenges include lack of privacy, social instability, and a general social stigma governing sexual behavior. We seek to create a new normal in which there is easy access to clinics for sexual health-related diagnoses and support, maintaining patient dignity in the process.

Through an appointment-scheduling platform using USSD technology along with an SMS component, we are providing access to diagnosis and treatment, as well as, allowing clinics the opportunity to provide psychosocial support to improve appointment and prescription adherence all via a mobile device as mobile penetration is over 90% in 2016. 

Through this, Cumasu came to the conclusion that we envision a world in which every human including marginalized communities receive access to proper healthcare as dignified participants through the leveraging of technology and collaboration to tackle the stigma around sensitive diseases, and ultimately connect care providers with those in need of care.

Primary Assets:

Startup Experience - Sohrab Co-founded Bean Voyage in 2015 to empower women coffee farmers in Costa Rica to enhance their income by 300% via an e-commerce platform. 

Education - Sohrab majored in Linguistics, as well as, in Business and Non-profit Management at Earlham College which has aided him in adapting to other cultures through a lens of language. He has also learned basic skills such as accounting, business plan writing, and grant writing among many more. 

Incubator - Sohrab is currently attending an incubator for social entrepreneurs called the Watson Institute based in Boulder, CO where he receives both mentorship and the tools on essential understanding and acknowledgement of the challenge he is tackling, as well as, further team building skills which are essential in Sohrab’s pursuit to build a team on the ground in Nairobi, Kenya.

Mentors -

Founder/CEO Stevan P. Simich and VP of Product Rob Blatchley from Mogli SMS provide SMS solutions for organizations globally. 

Eric Glustrom as an EchoingGreen and Ashoka Fellow is guiding me in expanding my supporting network on the ground as he has extensive experience working on the ground in East Africa. 

KANCO - KANCO as a partner, has a membership of over 1,200 organizations and numerous individuals that are networking, collaborating and are bound together by a common vision of an HIV, AIDS, TB and other public health issues of importance in  Kenya. 

Developer -

Gerald Ogola from Nairobi, Kenya, is a mobile applications developer who graduated from Strathmore University and has extensive experience in developing various USSD platforms. 

Brian Lyuba is by trait a web applications developer based in Nairobi, Kenya who will be responsible for building our website mycumasu.com in which users will have dashboards unique to them and their needs. 

Support - I have seasoned entrepreneurial support and guidance by Wyclife Omondi and Sonia Kabra, founders of Buupass based in Nairobi, Kenya working with USSD Technology with an SMS component.

Passion - Sohrab Amiri is fully committed to seeing this project be piloted with one health clinic on the ground. He will be building up his network and forming partnerships with different organizations, clinics, and communities. He will also be building up a team with identified positions by contacting professors and students from the University of Nairobi and Strathmore University

The Technology

On a daily basis, we have many things we interact with but we have actually never known their real name. USSD is one of them. It stands for Unstructured Supplementary Service Data which is a function of your mobile device allowing you to dial numbers on your phone when you want to call somebody. However, instead of calling somebody, you are dialing a set of 3 digits and * and # to access an application provided to you by your network provider.

Think of any operation one does on their cell phone which is not text, internet or making calls. Let us pick an operation, for example checking credit or buying bundles on your cell phone. The process normally involves entering a number in your cell phone with a unique structure. Imagine typing in *473# on your cell phone.

Interactive USSD applications are ubiquitous in the African mobile ecosystem. USSD is universally accessible on any mobile phone, making it a powerful tool for data collection. Through USSD technology, Cumasu will be able to make use of the robust analytics to help monitor appointment and prescription adherence as we will receive feedback in reflection to the questions we will be texting the patients. The USSD gateway is built to handle thousands of simultaneous requests at any one time. Cumasu can give anyone with a mobile device access to structured information via the interactive nature meaning we can layer authentication and leading questions to deliver the right information.

Under this link, you may find a video demonstrating an animation of the user interface of the Cumasu 1.0 platform.

The Requested Funding/Budget

Our start-up is in need of $3,984 to run a proof-of-concept of Cumasu 1.0 with health clinics with the help of KANCO to have a strategic plan for improvements and functionalities for Cumasu 2.0. These are the expenses associated with the pilot project after extensive research and discussions with locals living in Nairobi, Kenya with these breakdowns:

1. $2,000 for the development of Cumasu 1.0 which will be paying for various expenses associated with the development, as well as, animators. 

2. $213 for a shared USSD code for 4 months by Africa's Talking 

3. $514 for the flight from Frankfurt to Nairobi (round-trip, 01/10/18 - 03/16/18)

4. $700 for lodging  (65 days)

5. $260 for nourishment (considering $3-5 for two meals each day)

6. $126 for transportation within Nairobi with Matatus

7. $51 for Visa for 3 months

8. $120 for Yellow Fever Vaccination in Germany

This brings it to a total of $3,984 in order to begin the pilot project starting January 10th, 2018 until March 16th, 2018. 

The minimum viable product of Cumasu 1.0 functioning on any mobile device will entitle these functions:

Functionalities for the patient:

1. Schedule initial appointments

2. Reschedule appointments

3. Request test diagnosis result

Functionalities for the clinic:

1. Send delays or cancellations to scheduled appointments

2. Send SMS reminders for appointment and prescription

3. Make data-driven decisions through assessment of certain health recommendations via our robust data analytics

Functionalities for the Cumasu team:

1. Web platform will demonstrate data on appointment attendance and prescription adherence

2. Data will allow for us to make certain health recommendations in collaboration with health clinic

Outcomes

1. Develop the Minimum Viable Product Cumasu 1.0 by December 18th, 2017

2. Pilot run Cumasu 1.0 with a health clinic

3. Gather data of proof on improvements of appointment and prescription adherence

4. Build partnership with a health clinic to continue working with them

5. Receive feedback from the clinic and patients to iterate on Cumasu 1.0 and use all our learnings to develop a strategic plan for Cumasu 2.0

Measurement

Part of Cumasu’s commitment is to demonstrate the impact the mobile platform will have for health clinics and the patients we wish to serve. Therefore, Cumasu promises to track its impact through these measurements to demonstrate them to each supporter and the public:

1. USSD Technology allows with the robust analytics to monitor appointment and prescription adherence to see via the web platform how many people attended their appointments, as well as, understand if it improves prescription adherence

2. Pre and post interviews with both health clinic practitioners and patients

3. Video/Photo documentation of the progress of the development of Cumasu 1.0 and the work with health clinic and patients based on consent

4. Newsletters will be written once a month summarizing each month’s work, progress, and experience to share via social media, as well as, each supporter. Within the newsletter, feedback from both patients and health practitioners in reflection to Cumasu 1.0 will be shared

Now imagine you are again in Maureen's shoes and you were aware of the benefits that come with using the Cumasu application. Imagine you could have simply scheduled an appointment in privacy and see a doctor. Imagine you would have received constant reminders and support from the health facility and the Cumasu team to stay on your prescribed treatment in order for you to live a more prolonged life, as well as, be equipped with the information and motivation to battle the stigma around your disease. HIV is not a death sentence anymore, and we at Cumasu made it our mission to restore the dignity of people suffering from diseases that are coupled with social stigma, and ultimately empower their voices. 

We at Cumasu, thank you sincerely for your support!

Sincerely,

The Cumasu Team
story_txt: Thank you to everyone who contributed to our project in Round 1. Your contributions will help us fly our founder Sohrab Amiri on the ground and pay for expenses related to his stay for 2 months to work with developers and health facilities. In total, we have raised $1,030 and for that, we are incredibly thankful to those who have shown support and trust into our Cumasu team to fulfill this project. However, we still are in need of funding to ensure that Cumasu can run its Pilot Project in order to see how best we can work with health facilities and patients to serve them with the necessities to ensure an improved adherence of appointments and prescription intake for sensitive diseases such as HIV/AIDS. We will include the link to our first round of the sincere support we have received to our pilot project efforts thus far. The description of the previous campaign will help demonstrate what will happen with the funding we have raised thus far. IntroductionImagine your name is Maureen from Nairobi, Kenya, working as a hairdresser. You are the only breadwinner for your parents and siblings sometimes working 15 hours a day. You start catching a cold that you cannot seem to shake off, your vision starts to blur, and you are losing a significant amount of weight over time. Despite knowing how important your vision is for your work, you ignore the symptoms. The stigma around it limits your access to diagnosis and treatment. Finally, after your sister was able to convince you, you went to a local hospital and got tested for HIV. You are HIV positive. How could this have happened to you?After a while, the untreated HIV made you blind and you could no longer work because of how long you had to wait to seek diagnosis and treatment due to fear of the stigma around it. Now you are 34 with no partner or children, and you have been contemplating suicide. Maureen's story is the embodiment of many more people in which HIV/AIDS has left people in unstable positions within society, ultimately killing them prematurely. According to Avert, there are 4,500 new HIV infections every day among adults 15 years and older. 37% of those infections are among young people (aged 15-24 years), and this is an even worse statistic when we find out that women in the same age group have a higher HIV prevalence than men in the same age group.My story begins with my parents fleeing to Germany as political refugees. Racism left me ostracized at a young age. From those experiences, questions related to social stigma have been a part of me ever since I can remember. And they have, in part, led me to start my venture, Cumasu, which seeks to address the lack of access to healthcare faced by marginalized communities in developing nations. Specific challenges include lack of privacy, social instability, and a general social stigma governing sexual behavior. We seek to create a new normal in which there is easy access to clinics for sexual health-related diagnoses and support, maintaining patient dignity in the process.Through an appointment-scheduling platform using USSD technology along with an SMS component, we are providing access to diagnosis and treatment, as well as, allowing clinics the opportunity to provide psychosocial support to improve appointment and prescription adherence all via a mobile device as mobile penetration is over 90% in 2016. Through this, Cumasu came to the conclusion that we envision a world in which every human including marginalized communities receive access to proper healthcare as dignified participants through the leveraging of technology and collaboration to tackle the stigma around sensitive diseases, and ultimately connect care providers with those in need of care.Primary Assets:Startup Experience - Sohrab Co-founded Bean Voyage in 2015 to empower women coffee farmers in Costa Rica to enhance their income by 300% via an e-commerce platform. Education - Sohrab majored in Linguistics, as well as, in Business and Non-profit Management at Earlham College which has aided him in adapting to other cultures through a lens of language. He has also learned basic skills such as accounting, business plan writing, and grant writing among many more. Incubator - Sohrab is currently attending an incubator for social entrepreneurs called the Watson Institute based in Boulder, CO where he receives both mentorship and the tools on essential understanding and acknowledgement of the challenge he is tackling, as well as, further team building skills which are essential in Sohrab’s pursuit to build a team on the ground in Nairobi, Kenya.Mentors -Founder/CEO Stevan P. Simich and VP of Product Rob Blatchley from Mogli SMS provide SMS solutions for organizations globally. Eric Glustrom as an EchoingGreen and Ashoka Fellow is guiding me in expanding my supporting network on the ground as he has extensive experience working on the ground in East Africa. KANCO - KANCO as a partner, has a membership of over 1,200 organizations and numerous individuals that are networking, collaborating and are bound together by a common vision of an HIV, AIDS, TB and other public health issues of importance in  Kenya. Developer -Gerald Ogola from Nairobi, Kenya, is a mobile applications developer who graduated from Strathmore University and has extensive experience in developing various USSD platforms. Brian Lyuba is by trait a web applications developer based in Nairobi, Kenya who will be responsible for building our website mycumasu.com in which users will have dashboards unique to them and their needs. Support - I have seasoned entrepreneurial support and guidance by Wyclife Omondi and Sonia Kabra, founders of Buupass based in Nairobi, Kenya working with USSD Technology with an SMS component.Passion - Sohrab Amiri is fully committed to seeing this project be piloted with one health clinic on the ground. He will be building up his network and forming partnerships with different organizations, clinics, and communities. He will also be building up a team with identified positions by contacting professors and students from the University of Nairobi and Strathmore UniversityThe TechnologyOn a daily basis, we have many things we interact with but we have actually never known their real name. USSD is one of them. It stands for Unstructured Supplementary Service Data which is a function of your mobile device allowing you to dial numbers on your phone when you want to call somebody. However, instead of calling somebody, you are dialing a set of 3 digits and * and # to access an application provided to you by your network provider.Think of any operation one does on their cell phone which is not text, internet or making calls. Let us pick an operation, for example checking credit or buying bundles on your cell phone. The process normally involves entering a number in your cell phone with a unique structure. Imagine typing in *473# on your cell phone.Interactive USSD applications are ubiquitous in the African mobile ecosystem. USSD is universally accessible on any mobile phone, making it a powerful tool for data collection. Through USSD technology, Cumasu will be able to make use of the robust analytics to help monitor appointment and prescription adherence as we will receive feedback in reflection to the questions we will be texting the patients. The USSD gateway is built to handle thousands of simultaneous requests at any one time. Cumasu can give anyone with a mobile device access to structured information via the interactive nature meaning we can layer authentication and leading questions to deliver the right information.Under this link, you may find a video demonstrating an animation of the user interface of the Cumasu 1.0 platform.The Requested Funding/BudgetOur start-up is in need of $3,984 to run a proof-of-concept of Cumasu 1.0 with health clinics with the help of KANCO to have a strategic plan for improvements and functionalities for Cumasu 2.0. These are the expenses associated with the pilot project after extensive research and discussions with locals living in Nairobi, Kenya with these breakdowns:1. $2,000 for the development of Cumasu 1.0 which will be paying for various expenses associated with the development, as well as, animators. 2. $213 for a shared USSD code for 4 months by Africa's Talking 3. $514 for the flight from Frankfurt to Nairobi (round-trip, 01/10/18 - 03/16/18)4. $700 for lodging  (65 days)5. $260 for nourishment (considering $3-5 for two meals each day)6. $126 for transportation within Nairobi with Matatus7. $51 for Visa for 3 months8. $120 for Yellow Fever Vaccination in GermanyThis brings it to a total of $3,984 in order to begin the pilot project starting January 10th, 2018 until March 16th, 2018. The minimum viable product of Cumasu 1.0 functioning on any mobile device will entitle these functions:Functionalities for the patient:1. Schedule initial appointments2. Reschedule appointments3. Request test diagnosis resultFunctionalities for the clinic:1. Send delays or cancellations to scheduled appointments2. Send SMS reminders for appointment and prescription3. Make data-driven decisions through assessment of certain health recommendations via our robust data analyticsFunctionalities for the Cumasu team:1. Web platform will demonstrate data on appointment attendance and prescription adherence2. Data will allow for us to make certain health recommendations in collaboration with health clinicOutcomes1. Develop the Minimum Viable Product Cumasu 1.0 by December 18th, 20172. Pilot run Cumasu 1.0 with a health clinic3. Gather data of proof on improvements of appointment and prescription adherence4. Build partnership with a health clinic to continue working with them5. Receive feedback from the clinic and patients to iterate on Cumasu 1.0 and use all our learnings to develop a strategic plan for Cumasu 2.0MeasurementPart of Cumasu’s commitment is to demonstrate the impact the mobile platform will have for health clinics and the patients we wish to serve. Therefore, Cumasu promises to track its impact through these measurements to demonstrate them to each supporter and the public:1. USSD Technology allows with the robust analytics to monitor appointment and prescription adherence to see via the web platform how many people attended their appointments, as well as, understand if it improves prescription adherence2. Pre and post interviews with both health clinic practitioners and patients3. Video/Photo documentation of the progress of the development of Cumasu 1.0 and the work with health clinic and patients based on consent4. Newsletters will be written once a month summarizing each month’s work, progress, and experience to share via social media, as well as, each supporter. Within the newsletter, feedback from both patients and health practitioners in reflection to Cumasu 1.0 will be sharedNow imagine you are again in Maureen's shoes and you were aware of the benefits that come with using the Cumasu application. Imagine you could have simply scheduled an appointment in privacy and see a doctor. Imagine you would have received constant reminders and support from the health facility and the Cumasu team to stay on your prescribed treatment in order for you to live a more prolonged life, as well as, be equipped with the information and motivation to battle the stigma around your disease. HIV is not a death sentence anymore, and we at Cumasu made it our mission to restore the dignity of people suffering from diseases that are coupled with social stigma, and ultimately empower their voices. We at Cumasu, thank you sincerely for your support!Sincerely,The Cumasu Team

story:
OVERVIEW

What do we want to make?

We are making a free phone app and web platform (computer) that will help you manage your symptoms and quickly figure out what works best for you in improving your condition.

For details on how exactly the app will help you accomplish this, check out the features section below.

Why are we crowdfunding?

For a project of this magnitude, we need our team to be engaged full-time - especially the software engineers. We are gathering funds from the community to pay for our basic living expenses and the wages of any engineers we bring onto the team.

For details on how we plan to utilize the money, as well as the rewards you’ll receive for contributing, see the section titled “How your donation helps” and “Perks” below.

Before you read on:

The images used are not taken from the actual app. They are mock-ups we’ve created in order to convey our vision. With your help, they can become reality. Without it, they’ll remain mock-ups for longer. 

If you have questions that aren't addressed in the FAQ section below, feel free to message us through Indiegogo or email us directly at contact@joinaics.com

 

FEATURES

Tracking

We believe that in order to make progress, you need a clear picture of your health. Thus we begin by enabling you to easily keep track of how you’re feeling, what medications/supplements you’re taking, treatments you’re trying, etc. Here’s an example where a user has just finished eating, so she wants to record her post-meal fatigue, temperature, and mood.

 

Visualizing

So you’ve kept track of your health for a few weeks, aren’t you curious to see how it changed during that time? Using the AICS app, you’ll be able to SEE it. It’s hard to view the big picture when you’re using journals or spreadsheets (or not tracking at all!!), so we’re going to make it easy to study your data visually. You’ll be able to quickly find answer to questions like:

  • How much did my energy increase when I removed dairy from my diet?
  • I feel like my joints hurt more when my temperature is low. Is there a correlation here?

Here’s an example of a user who is studying the relationship between her Thyroid Panel values, mental clarity and energy over the course of a year. Interesting….

 

Aggregating Data

As more people use our app, we’ll be able to gather their information and turn it into a resource. That means your efforts can help someone else figure out their health! By leveraging not only your health data, but the data of the entire community, we’ll provide you with insights and answers you would have spent weeks or months searching for before.

  • What’s working well for others with similar symptoms?
  • I’m undiagnosed, do my symptoms match with a lot of people who have Hashimoto’s?

 

 

Group Experiments

You want to try a magnesium protocol? So do hundreds of other people! By participating in a group experiment, you can compare your progress with others trying it with you. This will also help practitioners better understand treatments and make improvements to their protocols. When you join an experiment, we’ll make it very easy to understand what treatments you should take, what you need to track, and what sort of science is taking place behind the experiment.

 

Practitioners

If you’ve ever wished to find the right doctor, one that listens to you and never asserts that it’s in your head, here’s a solution. There are many practitioners who specialize in autoimmune disease and chronic illness management, and they want to connect with you too. Looking for a nutritionist specializing in IBS? An endocrinologist with Hashimoto’s experience? Filter your search and find the practitioner that best fits you!

 

How your Donation Helps

We set our flexible goal of $100,000 based on our hiring, equipment, and infrastructure needs. Everything we receive will go directly towards developing our platform. The more resources that we have, the faster we’ll be able to make that vision a reality.

Donations go toward: basic living expenses, hiring software engineers, equipment and infrastructure needs (development laptops and hosting services)

 

Perks

Our primary perk is Early Access. With early access, you'll be able to use the app before it is publicly released.

Citizen Scientist T-Shirt

 

 

The Alternative Autoimmune Cookbook

by Angie Alt

 

Roadmap to Remission: A Practical Guide to Hashimoto's Healing

by Marc Ryan, L.Ac.

 

Hashimoto's Thyroiditis: Lifestyle Interventions for Finding and Treating the Root Cause

by Izabella Wentz, PharmD

 

The Autoimmune Paleo Cookbook: An Allergen-Free Approach to Managing Chronic Illness

by Mickey Trescott

 

Perk 1: Meal for 2

Perk 2: Ticket for 1 to AICS Launch Party with founders

@ Mission Heirloom Cafe in Berkeley, California.

 

A seat on the AICS User Planning Panel 

This perk is for people who want to play an active role in the direction of the user-end of the platform, The User Planning Panel will have the ability to regularly communicate directly with our design and development team about what should be in the next release of the app. Also includes early access, feature requests, and priority personalized support. Seats are limited to 25.

 

Early Practitioner/Consultant Panel 

This perk is for doctors, dietitians, naturopaths, and other health coaches who want a new, data-centric way to interact with patients and clients. Panel members will have the ability to regularly communicate directly with our design and development team about what should be in the practitioner-end of the platform. Panel members will have early access to work with patients and clients through the AICS platform. Panel members will have lifetime access to the platform. Seats are limited to 25. 

 

Frequently Asked Questions

 

Who can see my data?

Your data is completely anonymous and private. No one can see your individual data but you and those you may choose to work with (a doctor, for example).

If everybody’s data is private, how do you gather community data?

Individual data will be aggregated anonymously. That means that we will take data that you put in, dissociate it from you as an individual, group it with everyone else’s data, and then only statistics will be publicly visible. That means when you look at community information, you’ll see patterns and correlations you are interested in, but no individual data.

If you don’t feel comfortable with us including your anonymized data in the aggregation, you can always opt out while continuing to use our other features.

I’m a doctor/dietitian/health coach and think that AICS would be really useful for me to work with patients/clients. How would this work in my practice?

Put simply, if you ask patients to keep journals or spreadsheets, or ask them how they’ve been feeling between visits, this app will be useful to you.

We want for doctors to be able to quickly understand a patient’s daily experience over the course of weeks/months. The app will save you time and give you detailed scientific data on their symptoms, environmental inputs, treatments, etc.

Being featured as a practitioner on the platform will also place you and your practice in front of thousands of potential clients who may be interested in working with you!

How will your app help me on my health journey?

The app will provide you information. Whether it’s information about yourself or the community, it will be scientific and easy to understand. Plus, your data will do a lot of the work for you! What do we mean?

We’ll help you analyze the data you’ve recorded to see what’s working, we’ll connect you to others in the community with relevant data or experiments, and we’ll direct you to new research applicable to you. It’s all about YOU, but WE do a lot of the work.

Keeping a journal or inputting data into spreadsheets requires lots of time and focus. Our app will keep your interactions quick and easy, allowing you to focus on your life.

What aspects of my life should/can I track?

We’ve designed the app so that you can record pretty much anything and everything that comprises your chronic illness experience. Think your fatigue may be related to your diet? Track it! Think selenium supplements will decrease your TPO antibodies? Track it!

How far along are you?

We’re currently wrapping up a closed beta (people trying out a simplified test-version of the app) where we focused on understanding how users engage with the app. We learned a lot from our wonderful beta testers (big thank you to our testers) and are excited to begin building the full app.

In order to focus on the project full-time, the team quit their jobs. After working on it part-time for months, we decided to dive in head-first to make this vision a reality. Our release date is dependent on funding - we anticipate the first early release of the app to be around February.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you recognize that data-centered collaboration is the key to fighting the chronic illness epidemic, there are two things you can do.

  • Contribute to our crowdfunding campaign above.
  • Share this campaign!
